posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18876142
That's not pathogenic food poisoning. That's either a food allergy, or you got something with a spoiled ingredient in it. Food poisoning of the type caused by bacterial pathogens takes time to develop. The bacteria need time to reproduce to the point where there is an immune response. This is the incubation period, as seen in any other sort of infection like the flu. You don't start experiencing symptoms of the flu the instant you inhale a couple of virus particles. It takes time for the virus to incubate and make you sick. Same for salmonella, any of the vibrios, shigella, et al. If you get sick within minutes of eating, you were either already sick, are having an allergic reaction, or ate spoiled food. Food poisoning is not instantaneous.

>>18866973
Former butcher here, don't buy a cow to kill and butcher if you have no experience, breaking down and butchering a cow is an extremely skilled job that you need years of experience to do correctly. First, it takes at least 2 people an entire day to break down a whole cow. You simply won't be able to do it yourself. Three skilled butchers with years of experience can maybe break down 3 halves of cattle in a day; you have absolutely no idea what you're doing and the meat will start going rancid before you've finished a quarter. And this is after they are slaughtered, bled and skinned before being delivered to the butcher. Second, you need a huge, completely sanitized workshop that is refrigerated. If your surfaces aren't perfectly sanitized and the temperature is above 10degrees C your meat will spoil. Third, most beef is air cured for about a week before it's broken down. You will need a huge walk in fridge with rails and hooks to hang your meat and cure it before cutting. Finally, you will need an industrial sized vacuum sealer to package the cuts and a hot water dipper to seal the bags. And most importantly, you literally don't know how to butcher anything and will inevitably ruin perfectly good cuts of meat.

I don't know about cows but I buy a pig from a local farmer once or twice a year along with my parents.
We select the pig when it's still a piglet and it is marked as ours. We go and visit it once in a while as it grows up so we see that it's thriving and having a good life. My niece pets it and feeds it treats.
We usually have a local butcher cut it up for us since he's a friend of the family and gives us a good price. We then have a family day of further processing the parts into mince, pate, bacon, sausages, brawn etc. Dinner that day is porkliver pate on bread and of course the tongue with mustard.
It would be a little cheaper to buy pork on sale at the grocery store, but the quality is better, we know the swine had a good life, and butchering day really is a nice family event.

So yeah, you'll want to look into local farms I guess.

>>18866973
Search the internet for farms around you. Most farmers haven't figured out to have an internet presence, so taking a drive around the country-side or visiting local or regional farmer's markets is also an option. I lucked out and was able to join a private association to buy grass-fed beef and raw milk directly from a local farmer. We purchased half a cow that I split with my family, it worked out to be around $3.50/lb hanging weight after the processing fee for the butcher. Don't butcher it yourself, you'd probably have to pick up the cow from the farm with a trailer and kill it yourself if you really wanted to do that. At that point you might as well just buy a calf and raise it yourself in your back yard or indoors. The beef we've gotten locally is superior to anything in the grocery store. The flavor is out of this world, very buttery and earthy. My only complaint is that the cuts are fairly small compared to the grocery store, but it's still cheaper per lb buying wholesale cow. Maybe the size of the cuts were bc of how I told the butcher to process it, or because the breed they raise are smaller than other cattle, or because they don't raise them as long before they slaughter them. I don't really mind eating smaller cuts, but that's the biggest complaint I have for my local farmer. Also in general, local meat will always come frozen, even at the farmer's market, it's really not that big of a deal. If you're buying from farmer's market retail, then you'll pay more than the grocery store. We also got a quarter pig last year, worth it 100%. Deep freezer is necessary. Again, don't butcher it yourself plz. Pic not related to half cow, pic is from another local farm.

>>18868221
To add to my post, it's probably more important to find a farmer that uses a trustworthy, local butcher than the actual farmer themselves. There have been many stories of local farmers sending their high quality cows to a butcher and getting shit meat back, different animal received than the one sent in. Also buying via a private association means that the meat is not for sale to the public, and most likely, it is not USDA inspected, so there are looser restrictions on where they can process the meat. My local farmer has an open door/farm 24/7/365 policy where you're welcome to visit anytime as a club member and inspect for yourself what is going on at the farm, state and federal agents are not welcome since it is a private club. Being a private association, they are not allowed to sell to the public at farmer's markets. It saves on costs on public regulation which they pass on to the club members, and it has allowed them to stay in business and not go under as a local family farm. I've been a member for almost 3 years and have always been satisfied with their quality, their chickens are better than any other farmer or grocery store in the region. They have raw milk butter that I don't really care for since it's very grassy and I don't like that flavor in my butter, but if you like Irish butter you'd probably love it. Thanks for listening to my blog post, go meet local farmers and give them your business.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Des Moines:
Bunch of good Vietnamese places due to the number of Vietnamese immigrants that moved there. I liked pho 888 best.
When I lived there although A Dong and C Fresh Market (an Asian grocery store with a small restaurant inside) were good too. There were good authentic Mexican places too although I can't remember their names. You had to travel to Ames for top notch Chinese, but that may have changed since I last lived there 8 years ago.
Zombie Burger (it's a zombie themed meme restaurant but the burgers are great)
Alpine Tap was my favorite bar.


Iowa City:
La Regia Taqueria (Mexican)
Szechuan House (authentic Chinese)
Deadwood (the best bar)
Mesa Pizza is probably my favorite pizza place.

Davenport (Quad Cities Area) I live here now:
Quad Cities style pizza (I prefer Harris but there are a number of places serving it). Happy Joe's (not Quad Cities style) invented taco pizza and theirs is really good. Lopiez is my favorite pizza place and serves NY style pizza.
The best Indian food is at a gas station in Moline (it's across the river from Davenport) called Preet Mini Mart. Check their schedule. I go on Thursday or Friday if I'm in that area for estate sales, but they might only serve the Indian food a few days a week.
There's a really good Vietnamese restaurant inside of Oriental Food Store in Davenport that's only open weekends. Oriental Food Store is the best Asian grocery on the Iowa side of the Quad Cities. T&T Asian Foods Market is the best Asian grocery on the Illinois side and has a bigger selection. I usually go there when I need noodles.
If you want authentic Chinese, I think the only place that serves it is 888 Bistro in Moline. Ask for the authentic menu.
Abarrotes Carrillo is a Mexican grocery store/restaurant.
Ross' Restaurant (get the Magic Mountain)
My favorite bar is Geezer's which is a total dive
HOOTERS

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18868489
>>18868502
Water heat ones are more common.

You heat water to correct temperature, don't have to care about contaminants from older heat pipe systems, don't need to care about the boiler giving uneven water temperature depending on time of day, etc. And don't have to pay for the heat loss between the boiler and the appliance.
And you still want a heater in case the boiler water is too cold, so 55ºC of water promised is 55ºC. Or even better: If you want a program with higher heat than the boiler provides, such as 70ºC it can do that.

Doesn't matter if its full size, cabinet narrow, or countertop size.

>>18871079
>I do. And that's the first thing I thought of too.
Hmm... I ran into a similar problem and it turned out because we live in area with Hard Water that you need to add Citric Acid powder (same stuff they use to coat sour candies) to breakdown the minerals (dissolved Magnesium & Calcium Carbonate) in water that will concentrate via repeat uses and any drying cycle and cake up the internal plumbing and rinse holes on the sprayer arm (similar to what can happen to bathroom shower spray-heads reducing water flow). You can buy a big bag of it on Amazon straight up, but also in a small inexpensive shaker labelled as Lemi Shine at the grocery store first and see if that helps.

Also make sure your dishwasher filter in the basin floor is clean, and if you don't have an air gap that the drain tube is run out in a High Loop configuration to get the waste water to exit properly and not back wash. It should literally look like giant hairpin U-Turn and not be straight.
https://homeinspectiongeeks.com/what-is-a-dishwasher-high-loop-and-why-do-you-need-one/

>>18861512
if its buds, 5g/100ml 80-85c, 15seconds then either +5 or +15 seconds with each additional steep. buds can get very bitter but i think they do better with longer gongfu steepings.
if its leaves the same but you can use full boiling, but tend to do better with shorter steeps. some people also simmer the leaves in a saucepan for a long time.

i find whites to be the hardest to brew right because they all seem to require different parameters where as black/oolongs/green ect call brew up well with the same parameters i.e all blacks behave the same, all whites behave differently at least for me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18861512
>>18862215
You need to full soak the buds to get them to start extracting, which takes a pretty long time. Depending on your preference, you can do a fairly long hard rinse, boiling water for 30s or more depending on how dense your buds are, or you can do a short rinse, 5-10s at with boiling water, then a long brew, say 30s with boiling water. Once the leaves seem soaked through, they'll noticeably extract much faster. Do 10-15s brews here, if your tea is pleasant but thin, use more leaf, I brew with a very high ratio of leaf to water for baihao yinzhen. If it starts to be astringent or develop off flavors, you can do your main brews at around 90C instead. Once the leaves start to thin out, I like to do a single minute long brew, then a five minute brew and end it.

It will depend on the leaves you have, but the basic profile should look like that. Long brew to soak the leaves and get them to open up a bit, successions of much shorter brews, a few long brews. At close to boiling or boiling water, but feel free to lower the temperature if you feel you need to.

>>18871841
My biggest advice is that real, professional tasting is hard, and you shouldn't worry about giving brief or simple tasting notes. Trying to force it doesn't really work. When you're starting out you'll mostly give notes like woody, nutty, earthy etc. as you taste more stuff and have a better calibration, you'll start to find different sorts of flavors that can be consistent across different teas that you'll want to look for words to describe. I think it's fun, but a lot of the cultural and focus around tasting is people like Mei Leaf, who do it as a performance and not as any serious exercise. China has a robust culture around tea tasting and evaluation, but it mostly hasn't been exported from what I've seen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: what's the general difference in taste between small and large leaf ripe pu-erhs?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18873668
This is very general
Smaller leafs and buds, stronger, more bitter, infuses faster, runs out out flavor in less brews. Larger leaves + stems, sweeter, more mellow, smoother, less strong brews but more of them.
But its going to vary based on processing, fermentation level, the batch of tea leaves used etc.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18874856
Like I said, I've experienced first-hand in various green tea drinking countries in Asia like Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and China, that they don't brew at a specific temperature, they just pour boiling water straight into the pot. If you go to these countries and suggest using 90 degree water you will just get laughed out of the room like the autist you are.

From my own personal experience, boiling water doesn't make green tea bitter. What makes it bitter is:
- shitty quality tea leaves, usually from a bag
- not allowing the leaves room to expand, such as using an infuser basket
- adding too many leaves to the pot

>>18872424
My research led me to discover this perfect recipe for short grain rice, but my rice cooker actually does a better job. My old zoji didn't, but this one does.

1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.

39. We use the term “surrogate activity” to designate an activity that is directed toward an artificial goal that people set up for themselves merely in order to have some goal to work toward, or let us say, merely for the sake of the “fulfillment” that they get from pursuing the goal. Here is a rule of thumb for the identification of surrogate activities. Given a person who devotes much time and energy to the pursuit of goal X, ask yourself this: If he had to devote most of his time and energy to satisfying his biological needs, and if that effort required him to use his physical and mental faculties in a varied and interesting way, would he feel seriously deprived because he did not attain goal X? If the answer is no, then the person’s pursuit of goal X is a surrogate activity. Hirohito’s studies in marine biology clearly constituted a surrogate activity, since it is pretty certain that if Hirohito had had to spend his time working at interesting non-scientific tasks in order to obtain the necessities of life, he would not have felt deprived because he didn’t know all about the anatomy and life-cycles of marine animals. On the other hand the pursuit of sex and love (for example) is not a surrogate activity, because most people, even if their existence were otherwise satisfactory, would feel deprived if they passed their lives without ever having a relationship with a member of the opposite sex. (But pursuit of an excessive amount of sex, more than one really needs, can be a surrogate activity.)

posts.sub: R8 my recipe for Chilli and Sea Bass
posts.com:
Ingredients:

4 sea bass fillets, skin on
Salt and black pepper
2 tbsp olive oil
1 red onion, chopped
2 cloves garlic, minced
1 red pepper, diced
1 green pepper, diced
1 tsp dried oregano
1 tsp ground cumin
2 tsp chilli powder
1 tsp paprika
1/2 tsp dried chilli flakes
400g canned diced tomatoes
400g canned red kidney beans, drained and rinsed
100ml fish stock
200g fresh green beans, trimmed and cooked
1 julienned carrot
Sliced cherry tomatoes, to garnish
Instructions:

Season sea bass fillets with salt and black pepper.
Heat oil in a large pan over medium-high heat. Cook the sea bass fillets, skin-side down, until the skin is crispy and golden, about 3 minutes. Transfer to a plate and set aside.
Add red onion, garlic, red and green peppers, oregano, cumin, chilli powder, paprika, and chilli flakes to the pan. Cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
Stir in the canned diced tomatoes, red kidney beans, and fish stock. Bring to a simmer.
Transfer the sauce to a blender and puree until smooth.
Return the pureed sauce to the pan and bring to a simmer.
Return the sea bass fillets to the pan, skin-side up. Spoon sauce over the fillets.
Cover the pan and cook until the sea bass is cooked through, about 10 minutes.
Serve the sea bass fillets with the chilli sauce, fresh green beans, julienned carrots, and sliced cherry tomatoes as a garnish.
(generated by ChatGPT)

>>18870943
They have humans monitoring security cameras. The point of increased automation is that you can have a single human operator managing the operations of say, 5 stores simultaneously. So if Karen walks into the store she can still ask to speak to the manager, but that manager can handle Karens at multiple locations and so is not underutilized as a burger flipper the rest of the day.

Similarly, vandalism or spills can be handled with a rapid response cleanup crew. You don't need instant cleanup response at a single location every five minutes -- you might need 2--4 cleanups at a location per day, so the crews can spread their services around locations, or they can be outsourced to a contractor servicing several different companies in the immediate area so they don't even have to drive around much (thus making it cheaper than doing it in-house).

If you look at the train industry, for example, automation doesn't mean that robots solve every single problem all the time 100% with no oversight -- it means a single person doing oversight and management can do so over many trains and routes at once, instead of a single train or segment of track as in the past.

The opening of McDonald's first fully automated location in Austin, Texas, could potentially signal a shift towards increased automation in the fast food industry. With automation, fast food restaurants may be able to operate more efficiently and with fewer labor costs. This could lead to lower prices for customers and higher profits for the companies.

However, it's important to note that the full impact of automation on the food and cooking industry is uncertain and will depend on how widely it is adopted and how it is implemented. Automation may also lead to job loss for employees in the fast-food industry which is a concern for many.

Additionally, automation may also change the way food is prepared and served, as machines and robots may be able to perform tasks more quickly and consistently than humans. This could lead to changes in the quality and taste of food, as well as changes in the customer experience.

In the long-term, it will be necessary to observe and evaluate the impact of automation on the food industry, including its effects on employment, food quality, and customer satisfaction.

This is the real problem. An ACTUAL solution to this would be to implement some sort of percentage cap of the company's yearly revenue that any single person in a given position can take home as income in companies with over a certain number of employees. The more money the company makes, the more money everyone working there makes, higher tier positions still make more, but the disparity between CEO and lowest paid worker is greatly reduced and wealth inequality in the country as a whole would be brought back to reasonable levels pretty quickly. I know there would be a lot of details to hash out in a system like this and the percentages would have to be calculated for each company, I don't think you'd really be able to standardize something like this but if there was a serious effort by the government to regulate and enforce this kind of thing you'd still have people being incentivized to work as hard as they can without leaving an option open for upper management to abuse the rest of the people working there and take home way more money than they really deserve at the expense of everyone else working for them.

what moka does differently is take away factors of control from your brew.
no: pressure, tamping, control of water input, control of water temperature, control of temperature of the overall vessel.

posts.com:
>>18873831
If you want single serve, I believe a standard ceramic v60 would do the trick. In my opinion, kalita wave style filters do best when there is an airgap on the sidewall, so i'm not too fond of my origami and prefer an actual wave or stagg x. Your personal taste will vary.
If you want to make multiple cups, seriously consider a 8-10 cup chemex. The funnex is an option, but I feel there is better single serve drippers out there.

>>18873838
The silt is part of the experience for a french press, but if it really bothers you consider getting a 200 micron filter device. It feels kinda wasteful discarding some of your grounds, but will negate your issue. You can also use the filter to help prevent paper/cloth filter clogging.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18873838
Watch for fines in your grinds. Give the brewing grinds a stir and time to settle to the bottom. Pour slowly and maybe discard the last couple ounces. You might even also spoon off the first crema as I find that really improves the clarity of the cup. The FP shouldn't rely on the screen. It helps but gravity does most of your filtering.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18875263
There's really no point in spending more on a French Press. Most of the "premium" features you'd get on more expensive models (borosilicate or stainless vs cheap soda-lime glass; dual wall/insulation vs single wall; etc) are kind of pointless in a French Press. Because it's an immersion brewer, you shouldn't be leaving the grounds and water in there long enough for heat loss to be an issue, and even the cheapest, thinnest soda-lime glass won't experience catastrophic thermal shock at 100°C. Now, having said all that, if my cheap chinkshit French Press broke, I'd probably replace it with an Espro P3. I'd be interested in seeing how/if the dual mesh basket affects the brew.

Sadly, no. By the time you get any where near a roi with a reliable machine capable of doing a 7-9 gram-in dose, you're going to be let done with maintenance, not to mention the cost of a grinder if you buy whole bean. An areopress setup with a fine mesh filter might be your best bet under that scenario (making an aeropresso shot and turning it into areopressano), but even a standard 6 ounce areopress coffee will take 11g of coffee, the only real consumables being a 2 cent filter, the coffee, and eventually the gasket.

>>18875903
Depends on how long it takes to release the liquid and start the process. I usually do a bunch at once so the caramelization doesn't start until all the liquid is gone at 60-90 mins. Then 2.5 hours is the best I can do. If you push it too fast you might burn a bit and that adds bitterness which you absolutely do not want. Best to go low and slow. Stir often. Don't add anything. Butter, onion, salt. Nothing else.

I love all your soups. I've had almost all of them and will make the ones I haven't. But we are talking GOAT here. And there is no soup more well known, comforting, or beloved as the humble chicken noodle soup. Everyone has had a cold and almost all of us have had bowl of chicken soup with it. If such a thing as comfort kino exists then that feeling every one of you got when you thought about that warm bowl on a cold night is it.

In all my life whenever I generally feel shitty chicken noodle has been there for me. All soups are beautiful. But there is only one chicken noodle.

genetics and an active and fulfilling social live are the most common correlations with longevity. Diet most definitely plays a major role too.

The diet aspect of both super old Italians and Japanese can be attributed to their diet being varied and diverse; they don't just eat fish and vegetables and carbs, they eat a variety of meats, fruits and vegetables, and grains, rather than eating the same few things most days. There's a saying in Japanese called "eat the rainbow" which means to try and have a diet consisting of foods that are multicolored like the rainbow. >>18869973
Lol. You don't know what "thermodynamics" are.

There is no such thing as a "calorie" in terms of human energy expenditure, because the human does not burn food and because our bodies are not a thermodynamically closed system since we are exchanging mass with the environment.

Due to this variable rate mass exchange that results in energy loss through loss of nutrients (piss, shit), you cannot correctly estimate the "calories out" part of your CICO nonsense.

By law, nutrition fact labels are not forced to be 100% accurate, because it's literally impossible. Nutrition fact label inaccuracy can be as high as 20% or higher BY LAW and much higher in practice. Also, the amount of chemical energy your body extracts from food is not the same amount of energy produced in the form of heat when that same food is burned in a calorimeter, because our bodies are not calorimeters lmao. This amount of chemical energy is vastly lower. These factors mean that you cannot properly estimate the "calories in" part of your nonsensical CICO equation.

The reason why CICO """works""" is because it grossly overestimates the "calories in" and underestimates the "calories out" so you end up literally starving yourself. This "works" short-term, but starvation reduces your basal metabolic rate (without even taking into account the change of muscle mass which affects BMR) with time which means that you need to eat less and less to sustain your weight loss. At some point, your BMR drops so low and you need to eat so little to sustain weight loss that you just can't go on psychologically and rebound into gorging yourself on food, resulting in rebound weight loss.

All of this is very well known by now and is the reason why statistically 95% of all diets fail. Because CICO bullshit never worked will never work long term.

I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I've recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called Linux, and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project.

There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine's resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called Linux distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux!

>>18872856
I believe ideally you should *warm* your non-coated stainless steel(~200°F), add oil, then continue heating to your desired cooking temp(300°-400°F).
Thermic shock and warping will still be an issue if you leave the empty pan unattended and add stuff to it after it's been superheated.
With a ceramic-coated or seasoned cast iron pan I don't think the pore stuff should be a thing and you can add the oil colder.

>>18872050
Cast iron has more mass therefore it has better thermal mass. Why is that important? Let's take one of the most used purposes for cast iron, pan seared steak. In pan searing a steak, surface temperature is critical to making a good sear. Once the steak is placed on the pan, the temperature will drop momentarily as the two surfaces work their way into equalizing their temperatures. A good sear requires maintaining as close temperature of the Maillard Reaction as possible, which is roughly around 357*F but requires a surface temperature greater than that since the steak is colder as both surfaces fight to equalize their temperatures. A cast iron skillet with more thermal mass than a stainless steel skillet will resist that temperature gradient longer than a stainless skillet because stainless steel is both less massive as well as less conductive.

With all that said however, I'm a stainless steel guy simply because itjustwerks™

>>18874654
If you are restoring an old, dirty pan from the flea market or fleabay, then this is good advice for an initial seasoning. If you're trying to build up a long-lasting seasoning this way, you will need to repeat this process many, many times. It can definitely work, but just understand that the natural seasoning in your grandma's pan got there after decades of daily use or use multiple times per day.

IMO, the best advice is to just cook in your pan and the seasoning will tend to build up naturally, but there are two complications. 1) Many ex-teflon users don't really know how to cook with oil and fuck up out of ignorance, and 2) if someone wants to cook meat in a new pan, right away, the seasoning will usually not be tough enough. Since most of the small scale/"boutique" cast iron manufacturers only ship their pan with an initial (thin) layer of seasoning, they tend to get a bad reputation when someone puts a steak into the pan, and then after cooking, they notice a steak-shaped spot where all the seasoning stripped off the cooking surface.

Just cook in the pan a lot. That's it. Even illiterate hillbillies can do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Why is calcium sulfate used in food?
Calcium sulphate is an additive used in the food industry which acts as a stabilising effect and helps to firm foods and regulate their acidity levels

>Sodium acid pyrophosphate can be used as a leavening chemical for bread to help it rise. If you have too much phosphorus in your diet and not enough calcium, it can be detrimental to your skeletal system.

>Dextrose is a simple sugar, and it's well-known that consuming too many simple sugars is bad for the health

>Fumaric acid is commonly used as a food additive to add flavor, as a coagulant, as a food preservative, and as an acid in leavening

>Monoglycerides are generally considered safe, but you should still limit your intake. They're commonly found in processed foods, so choose whole foods, like fresh fruits, vegetables, and legumes, or unprocessed meats, whenever possible.

>Sodium metabisulphite (SMBS), the commercially produced salt of sulphurous acid, is a preservative used to extend the shelf life of meat products such as fresh sausages and burgers, even though it can have adverse effects on some people, especially asthmatics.

>Calcium Propionate (also known as E282) is the calcium salt of propanoic acid. It is used as a food preservative and is commonly found in commercial bread and other baked goods. One human study linked propionate intake to the increased production of insulin

I hate almost everything flyover but overall I'd say Culvers is the best fastfood restaurant, though their fries aren't that great.

>>18861195
Didn’t drink until I was 17, at the after party to my high school ball (I guess burgers would call it prom). Then I got the taste for it.
Was fine for 2 years, alcoholic for 3, fine for another 3, alcoholic for another 3, and now I’m starting to clean up my act for my job. I know people here won’t sympathise or believe me, but my life has improved immensely in the last year through slow tapering.
I’m down to moderately drinking once a week, which is much better than being heavily dependant every day. It just took very small things like dropping a % per vol here and there, and buying slightly less every time you go to the shop.
I recently got back my taste for alcohol for the first time in god knows how long. I actually crave a good beer for the taste, or a good bourbon on the rocks.

tl;dr alcoholism sucks but you can still beat it by being smart. But I ain’t gonna blame you if you don’t want to, it’s your choice.

Maybe anything exotic, or something you don't normally get, you might not marinate at first.

>>18871915
Tesco is selling long-grain white rice for 0.48/kg right now. At that price, you'll need to spend 7.5 pounds per month on rice to get your basic caloric needs met. Lets say you get three quarters of your requirements from rice. THat lowers your spend to 5.62.

To fill out your diet, you'll need micronutrients, and protein. You have 23.8 pounds remaining. You can buy Red Lentils for 1.65/kg. At 1150 calories per kg, you could have 100 calories of lentils per meal, give you a spend of 4.95 on pulses.

You have 18.85 remaining. You still need a bunch of micronutrients and a small amount of animal protein. From here, it gets harder. You'll want to buy cheap vegetables like frozen peas. Spend 8 pounds on frozen vegetables, making sure to get enough vitamin C(hard to judge the most cost-efficient source for this, perhaps powdered drink crystals?)

For the final 10.85 pounds, you'll want eggs. I'm seeing 0.25 per egg, so 18 will cost you 4.5.

You can then spend the last bit on the cheapest meat you can find, and dole it out every couple of days. This doesn't include the cost of sauces and seasonings, but you can spend a negligible amount on them if you are judicious.

For the /fit/ bros among us, this is what I do

>Mix 200g of greek yoghurt with 120g of stevia
>Add 2 eggs and a bit of vanilla, then mix the entire thing
>Add 0kcal chocolate syrup (as much as you like, I go about 30ml), mix
>Add 90g of oatmeal flour (just grind them yourself in a blender), 25g of cocoa powder and as much protein powder as you want (I do 1-2 scoops)
>(Optional) add 50g of pure chocolate you cut up, or chocolate chunks

30 min in the oven and I like to set it for an entire day. Cut in 7 pieces and thats an easy delicious 10+ grams of protein chocolate brownie (for example for breakfast)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18869998
It's called cocoa powder. It's in literally every grocery store.

Depending on the brand you can get Dutch-processed or regular, and you should follow what the recipe asks for, because they have different acidity. Generally Dutch-processed is the chocolate flavor people want and expect, which is why it's more common, while non-Dutch processed is used for a little twist on flavor, or if some specific pH optimization is needed, or for color (namely red velvet cake).
https://www.seriouseats.com/difference-dutch-process-natural-cocoa-powder-substitute

>>18874556
>Why is it better than peanut butter that features emulsion agents?
Those emulsifiers dull the peanut flavor of natural PB and give a gluey consistency to it. When using the 100% natural stuff or making it yourself you'll be surprised how runny and clean-tasting the PB actually is. It's far more versatile in it's basic form.

Also as >>18874683 mentioned storing it upside down and importantly in the fridge keeps the fat from re-separating back out.

There's something about Chick Fil a that just mogs every other fast food establishment.

Maybe it's the top tier service, the 19-year-old waitresses that take your order with a genuine smile and a "my pleasure", I can tell their parents vote Republican every time I go.

Or maybe it's the original chicken sandwich (which was invented by Chick Fil a) that is perfectly cooked, it's not overly crispy or oily like Popeyes and nor does it taste like cafeteria food like the McChicken. It's perfectly cooked, generously sized and it's garnished with two perfectly placed pickles that you wouldn't think is enough but is, in fact enough.

Or maybe it's the enormous selection of sauces that clenches your thirst every time you go, it may be ranch or honey mustard or classic or buffalo or polynesian depending on your mood, but either way it makes you happy to be alive.

I refuse to visit any other fast food establishment, I'll frequent McD's once in a while for a quarter pounder but I'd be lying if I said it didn't leave me with a craving for the original chicken sandwich every time.

The thing about mushrooms and rinsing;
If you're cooking at home you can rinse them and cook with them right away and it's fine. They won't get soggy.

You're running a restaurant, however, you might get a big crate of mushrooms and Tuesday and clean them all so they're ready to use for the rest of the week. If you rinse those with water they might be soggy and sad by the end of the week, so you have to clean those with a dry brush instead.

That sounds like something ATK would have done so I went looking and came up with this:
https://www.americastestkitchen.com/cooksillustrated/how_tos/6501-best-bang-for-your-bay-leaf
>Most recipes that call for bay leaves add them to the pot early on and leave them in for the duration of cooking—sometimes as long as several hours. But does it really take that long to extract this herb’s flavor? To find out, we simmered bay leaves in tomato sauce and in lightly salted water (to eliminate the distraction of competing tastes) for varying lengths of time. In both liquids, the bay leaf’s herbal notes were noticeable in as little as five minutes, but it took about an hour for the full spectrum of its more than 50 flavor compounds to become apparent. The moral of the story: Feel free to add bay leaves to dishes with cooking times as short as a few minutes, but to really maximize their flavor, simmer them for a full hour.

Also Chris Kimball (the bowtie guy that left ATK to start not-ATK) did a segment on Bay Leaves (google it since 4chan thinks linking the video is spam).
tl;dw is he can't taste them and his support staff say there is a difference between Turkish Bay Leaves which are the dried common variety we are used to which are subtle flavorings and Californian Bay Leaves that are typically sold fresh and extremely overpowering. I had no idea there even was more than one kind of bay leaf so there's that.

https://www.seriouseats.com/ask-the-food-lab-whats-the-point-of-bay-leaves
SE says that if you toss a fistful of bay into a pot of boiling water for five minutes you'll get a menthol-like flavor sipping the liquid after.

Ethan Chlebowski did a video on the subject too for good measure:

Dasani Hate Explained:
The concept of buying single servings of drinking water is a capitalistic scam because majority of municipalities have clean, safe to drink, highly processed, purified tap water with additives available for a fraction of the cost. One of the perceived appeals in favor of Big Water is they use marketing tactics to convince people they are selling somehow "Better water" ... it's crisp, refreshing, hydrating, alkaline, electrolyte, ionized, reverse osmosis filtered... Most of it's crap anyways, the only water that really has benefits above others is "natural spring water," and this is because natural water rubs against sediments and collects minerals that we need for hydration. So this is also why waters like Dasani are criticized, because they source their water from municipal sources. So essentially they're just putting tap water in a bottle and charging you a hell of a lot compared to the cost of running the tap. If you're going to spend your dollars on water, make it spring water.

>>18873042
I have no problems with mine. Maybe your temperature control unit is broken. It shouldn't just be on or off. The dial on mine increases temperature from a low to a high heat, and on any certain setting it maintains +/- 10 degrees via cycling on and off. I used a temperature probe directly on the glass top to measure it over 1 hour.
Drawbacks are it takes a long time to get to a stable temperature (preheat it for 20m to avoid this) and it loses temperature easily if you add cold food (use a heavy thick pan).

posts.com:
i have had an epiphany
usually when i make a stew in my slow cooker for my weeks' dinners, by the 3rd or 4th day in the refrigerator it starts getting old. not going bad but definitely growing more bacteria as I get lots more gas then.
this issue never happens when i have chili week or cook jambalaya and i realize the common thread between those two is my use of tomato sauce. so i took my stew meat, potatoes, carrots, and put them in the pot like normal, but this time I put in 8oz of tomato sauce to the stew. my theory is that the acidity is hostile to bacterial growth and will prove to cause my stew to stay fresh longer in the refrigerator throughout the week as I eat it for dinner each night.
my only unsolved mystery left is how tomato sauce will impact the flavor of my stew as this is untreaded grounds I am entering. the slow cooker is currently running and will complete tonight, I am excited to find out!

Why didn't you reduce it more? Just let it cook down. The beef hasn't taken on any of the flavor yet, to say nothing of the raw ass onions. The tomato chunks too have yet to break down. It looks like you just dumped a bunch of shit cooked separately into a pot of beef broth.
Chili has three basic steps - You cook the meat, you sautee or sweat the veggies in the rendered fat, then you add in the meat, beans etc and let it stew. At least 30-45 minutes, ideally twice that. You want everything to reduce and release as much flavor as possible. It's a one pot meal so I really hope you're not using an instant pot. That's a good way to have it come out mediocre.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18870519
>prosciutto
here you go
Prosciutto is made from high-quality pork legs. The meat is covered in salt and left to rest for a few weeks. During this time, the salt draws out blood and moisture, which prevents bacteria from entering the meat (and is why it's safe for us to eat it "raw"). Salting the meat also causes the flavors to become more concentrated.

After the salting process, the pork legs are washed, seasoned by hand (often according to a secret family recipe), and left to dry-age at a controlled temperature for 14 to 36 months. It is the combination of salt, air, and time that gives prosciutto its sweet and delicate flavor.

Apeaking as an Italian, making prosciutto requires quite a bit. You need to take a whole pork leg, cure and salt it, you need to hang it in a cellar for months or even years and to know/learn how to check it to see if it is going good. And in the end you get several kgs of prosciutto, so unless you are doing this for the whole extended family it is much better to buy some.
If you want to try to learn I suggest starting smaller, like salame or lucanica.

I drink lots of vodka. That cleans out my system, and even cleans my teeth (I haven’t brushed in years, and haven’t had a cavity since).

I also eat a liverwurst sandwich pretty much every day – to counterbalance the effects the vodka has on my liver. I make my sandwiches on seeded rye (because it’s the healthiest bread), with mayo (because eggs are the best protein; I use kewpie, because the msg makes it taste better), coarse mustard (good for the white blood cells), zucchini pickles (because they taste good), and a bunch of baby spinach (just for filler; it could honestly be left out).

I also eat a lot of canned fish (mostly sardines, but also the occasional fancy smoked oysters) on saltines. They give you all your essential amino acids, and provide a nice opportunity to try out various hot sauces, which are generally very low in calories, while high in flavor and immensely prodigious to healthiness.

Aside from that, I drink large amounts of water (anywhere between ice-cold to slightly chilled) every day, always through a straw, and sometimes with a lemon wedge.

To each their own, I say, but I’m just shy of 30 and am doing better than most of you.

To answer your q: the only thing you can really do with green curry paste is make green curry. Red paste is more useful. If you're looking for something not as soup-like as a curry, I've made green curry mixed shellfish risotto with green curry paste. The citrus and coriander flavors of the paste make it ideal for seafood, especially shellfish. I've also made green curry mussels. While I've never made it, I'm sure green curry roasted fish would be lovely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18872189
Yeah, ตะไคร่ is Lemongrass. Also what is translated as fennel seed is actually cumin seed and coriander balls are coriander seeds. Those two are toasted in a pan before grinding. If you're going to do that I'd recommend toasting seperatly because cumin seeds take much less time than coriander. Burnt cumin is not great, for you information.
The chili peppers he uses are in chronological order: prik chee fah (1000 scoville), prik jinda (75.000 scoville) and prik kee noo (90.000). Assuming you don't have those chillies you will need to substitute those with other chillies. I hope you have thai chillies that are available to you. If not then even something like jalepenos with (preferably yellow) habanero's would work. A nice trick to make your green curry look even more green is to grind or puree thai basil in a bit of coconut milk. Make sure to add it only at the end of the cooking process because the thai basil taste is sensitive to heat.

My source for the scoville amount is this website, quite handy:
https://www.thai-food-online.co.uk/blogs/thai-food-online-blog/thai-chillies-scoville-scale

Green curry should have - in my opinion - a much more fiery and grassy taste compared to to red curry, which is milder and has a bit of smokiness because of the dried red chillies it uses.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18871597
Basically, dilute it with stock and milk products. Get dialed in where it tastes good to you with stock (or if severe pleb water), then get the cream/milk/sour cream dialed in for a creamy aspect. Ideally in parallel you'd be cooking rice and veggies/meat and you'd dump the veggies/meat into the curry for a "hey nice to meet you", then serve with rice.

You start by frying the paste in oil or a little bit of coconut milk (which eventually separates into oil), then you add liquids
Because oil carries flavor better and frying changes the flavor of the raw ingredients

Pickled eggs are a traditional delicacy that can be found in many cultures around the world. They are typically made by hard-boiling eggs and then pickling them in vinegar or brine. Some people really enjoy pickled eggs, as they have a unique tangy and savory flavor. However, taste is quite subjective and others may not like it.

As for the brands, it may vary depending on the location, but some popular brands that produce pickled eggs are:

Reese's Pickled Eggs
Egglands Best Hard-Cooked Peeled Eggs
Aunt Nellie's Pickled Beets and Eggs
B&G Pickled Eggs

It is also possible to make your own pickled eggs by boiling the eggs and then pickling them in vinegar, spices, and herbs.

>>18873738
The best pickled eggs are the ones you pickle yourself.
>Half and half of water and vinegar
>Salt, herbs, and spices
>Simmer together and pour over hard boiled eggs
>Seal and leave in the fridge for a few days
I enjoy the classic bread and butter, dill and caraway, spicy curry and sweet soy sauce, and super spicy pepper with slivered carrots and garlic. For the holidays I use pickled eggs to make deviled eggs, and I prefer the ones with beet juice since it turns them a cute shade of pink :3
For long term shelf stable eggs there is a different method to fully sterilize them, but fridge pickling eggs is easy, tasty, and customizable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18873738
>>18874235
As for the flavor they taste like hard boiled eggs, but the egg white part of the egg will absorb the flavor of the vinegar and whatever flavorings you add. It gets stronger the longer it sits. If you are hesitant and don't want to make a whole batch because you think you might not like them, take an egg and dip it in relish. It will taste similar. Then make a single mason jars worth, about half a dozen.
You can eat them as they are or use them for anything you'd typically use a hard boiled egg for like deviled eggs, egg salad, sliced up for sandwiches, and salads or ramen toppings.
I love pickled eggs.

From a Greek Orthodox perspective, as far as fasting goes, you either try to eat fast-appropriate food with greater or lesser effort, or you don't even try to fast. The religious rule of fasting exists to build character, primarily temperance and humility. Outside monastic communities it is not a strict law and more of an ideal, and for laymen it is usually considered enough to simply try your best. Not to get into the finer details, but there is also a strong tradition of vegetarian cooking which exists in order to properly celebrate religious feast days which occur during the fast. The food is meant to taste good, but it is very obviously lighter vegetarian cuisine.
Unlike the Catholics, fish is not licit during the fast (although it is seen as a "less-bad" food, in some places) and in fact in most places, the ideal fast excludes all dietary oils as well - which is by far the least-followed restriction among laymen for obvious reasons.
In this light, it is pretty clear where Beyond Meat and similar products belong. They are, at best, a "less-bad" food like fish, but fake meat products embody principles opposite to the ideal fasting food. The reason there is a "debate" is basically that disinterested laymen who might feel community pressure to fast will try to find loopholes in their daily life, and since the point of the fasting rule is humility, if you are another layman and not a priest it is considered counterproductive to insist and posture over the dietary rule that others are following, for the same reason that you aren't supposed to act prideful over people who don't fast. Still, I think it's pretty clear to everyone that this is a loophole.
